Sometimes we find this ei altemating with ὁ, asin robigo (ἐρεύθω), metare (not different in origin from enitare).

In unaccented syllables before a vowel we get el, eg. in denuo (de novo), eibnuo (νεῦω), monui (mene-gre). This being so, ruo (ῥέω), pluo (πλέω), etc. must owe their vowel to the analogy of the compounded forms (cerreto, eto), otherwise we should have *reve *ploro (cf. the old Latin perplovere).

The combination eu only occurs in Latin in ltere, eben neu, ceu, seu, neuter, eto, and in breves, levis. Of these neu, ceu, seu, neuter are compounds (for ne-ee, etc).
